title: Compact compund planetary reducer (40:1)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
WARNING: print at your own risk, pieces may not fit without sanding!!!

Compound planetary reducer for NEMA17 (40:1)

Enclosed version with all tolerances adjusted for 3D printing!

About:

This reducer is designed to be mounted on top of a NEMA 17 standard stepper motor. It has a high reduction ratio of 40:1 in a very small package (only 17mm tall, and sized the same as NEMA17 motors (width and length of the housing).

Gear ratio: 40:1

Functioning principle explanation:

This system consists of 2 rings with inside gearing, one is fixed and the second is the output ring. All three planet gears are driven by the sun gear, and engage both rings at the same time.Each revolution of the planet carrier (here non-existent, but imagine it's there for the sake of easier explanation) will move the outer ring by 3 teeth (in the direction of the motor).

Additional parts:

The most important part you will need to successfully assemble this is a R-1650ZZ bearing (or similar, 5x16x5), the bearing should be press fitted into the output flange and onto the motor shaft. You will need at least 4 M3 screws to fasten this to the motor, and adittional 4 screws to fasten the cover plate.

NOTES:

  • If you plan to use this as a part of a functional mechanism, use plenty of grease or other lubricant!

Drawing with main dimensions:

print_settings.Notes:: Extrusion width 0.45 mm

description.text:
Hi everybody...
This is my first thing on thingiverse! I hope you will enjoy it!
Thanks to this improve you can make your prusa very silenced. If you use in silence mode it's easy to forget that it's working for you :D
You must print 4 x Prusa Damper part 1 and 4 x Prusa Damper part 2. Also i suggest to print the Prusa Damper Middle because offers more stability during the X axis movement.

If you want to fit the part 1 with the part 2 (it's not necessary) you can use Super Glue or acetone's drops (only if you print with ABS) onto the joints..

I made it with ABS... Probably work also with PLA and PETG... If someone want to try, give me a response so i can update this information tab.

Thanks to everybody... Enjoy the silence :D

Prusa I3 mk2s

50%

Extrusion width 0.45 mm

comments.text:
This really helped reducing most of the noise. There is still some high pitched sound that comes through, but it has improved significantly!
One thing that worries me is how unstable the machine becomes after this change even though I printed the parts for the middle as well (6 legs in total). As I print with it now I can see the entire machine rocking back and forth as the print head is moving rapidly, and it's a bit unsettling, although the machine produces as great prints as ever.

description.text:
Another digital bitz-box miniature mashup from public domain characters for those homebrew and Fallout miniature warefare players. Gammorians' Mariposa Mutant Army from the original Fallout, Fallout 2 and Fallout Tactics story-line, as well as, some characterful direction from the community of fan-made artwork.

I've also included the base concepts and "wasteland" weapons but, they are not exhaustive and I'm sure with a bit of cutting and assembling you could make them a bit more expressionistic!

Feel free to rescale miniatures as you wish or even go further and add "green stuff" to make them really tabletop playable !! For intended results print models in 15mm with 40+ infill.

I've attempted to recreate the character from the noted Fallout screenshot through the digital bitz-box miniature mashup using public domain characters. There are 2 variations: one with a range weapon, and one with a melee weapon. For best results print in 20mm scale or larger with 40% + infill and split in half on PLA. Designed best for print out on a SLA printer.

description.text:
Die Idee war einen Dual-Extruder für meine Prusa I3 zu designen. Aus Spaß am designen habe ich nun die komplette X-Achse, sowie den Spooler neu gezeichnet.
Ich habe diverse Prusa-Remixes ausprobiert. Die besten Ideen sind anschließend in dieses Design geflossen.
Alle Teile wurden von mir in Catia gezeichnet.

Als Hotend verwende ich zwei J-Head Hotends.

Für das Kalibrieren bin ich folgendermaßen vorgegangen:
Als erstes habe ich mir ein passendes Objekt gesucht:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1008954
Den X Versatz habe ich auf +20 und -20 mm eingestellt.
Nach dem ersten Layer sah man dass auch Y einen kleinen Versatz hatte (bei mir 2mm). Mit dem Messschieber nachgemessen und korrigiert.

Als Software verwende ich Repetier Host und Cura.
In den Cura Settings ist folgendes zu erweitern:
G-Codes -> Start G-Code:
nach der Zeile:
{IF_EXT0}M104 T0 S{TEMP0}
ist folgende einzufügen:
{IF_EXT1}M104 T1 S{TEMP0}

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hNI1wqUvXK7

This is a feeder for your reptiles, especially geckos. I use it if i am on my holidays and can not feed them everyday. It is very useful also for baby geckos. You just put the mealworms or half mealworms (in case you use it for baby geckos) into the tube and then turn the tube around and insert it into the base. Now the mealworms slowly fall out of the tube into the triangle piece and can be eaten by the reptiles. Also the mealworms can not escape because of the 1cm high walls. Although there are little tanks on the sides wich you can fill with sand so the feeder will not fall over. You can close the tanks with the little plugs so no sand will flow out.

I will upload pictures as soon as possible.

For this thing you will need:
1x base
1x tube
2x plug

If you have any questions comment down below.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10-25%

Notes:

I usually print it with a 0.4 nozzle at 60mm/sbut for the plugs i slow down to 30mm/s.
you will only need some support at the insert for the tube.
It took me around 2hours and 30minutes to print everything.

author: mingpoo

description.text:
Based on the wonderful model by Zydac http://www.thingiverse.com/Zydac
The Venus of Willendorf, found near the Danube River in what is now Austria, is one of the earliest examples of sculpture. It was believed to be made over 25,000 years ago. I thought it was appropriate to re-think it a little using Makerbot's 3d printing, which is really pretty new and revolutionary.
Maybe 25,000 years in the future, someone will find this and say "This multi-armed Venus is one of the earliest examples of 3D printing as an art form". We'll just have to wait and see :)
-Jason Bakutis 2012
The finish is just simple acrylic paints over a coat of grey primer.
A science fair project i'm helping with

Wanhao Duplicator i3 firmware. This firmware works with the original LCD and Melzi board.
I had to create a custom thermistor table because the standard board uses 10k pull-up resistors instead of 4.7K. (Not sure how good the table is.)
I also had to edit the config file for the Melzi board to get the lcd to work.
Marlin also has manual bed leveling enabled.(Use paper and tweak up/down until paper gives some resistance)

You will need to have a bootloader to update the firmware.
http://www.instructables.com/id/Using-an-Arduino-to-Flash-the-Melzi-Board-Wanhao-I/

comments.text: Thanks for your effort. I "ported" it to Marlin version 1.1.8, but ultimately ended up just replacing the 10K pull-up resistors with through hole 4.7Kohm on the board, and running standard marlin 1.1.8 instead. If you completely remove the 10K resistor on the hotend, you will be able to use a PT100 amplifier board, pulling the needed 5v from the FTDI 6 pin socket :-)

comments.text: The standard Repetier Firmware will be expecting 10k pull-up resistors so the Temp readings will be wrong. If you are using this firmware and you change the Thermistor table to  thermistor table 1 and recompile and upload it, should work perfectly. With the standard marlin thermistor table 1 expecting a 4.7k pull-up resistor the temperatures are doubled if 10k resistors are used. I am running this exact firmware with the exception of the thermistor table 99. I am using Thermistor table 1 with 4.7k resistors just like your board.

If you change the resistors that the melzi board uses for the thermistors from 10k to 4.7k you can use thermistor table 1 in marlin. I desolderd the standard surface mount resistors and replaced them with 4.7k resistors.
The standard melzi board uses 4.7k but the wanhao board uses 10k resistors.

title: SOTA 3-Band Vertical Antenne with Loading Coil
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the body for a 3-band, base loaded ham radio antenna for 40, 30, and 20m.
It is designed to be used with a 6m fiberglass mast from lambdahalbe.de; it may fit other similar masts.

You need 2mm gold-plated plugs (normally used for RC car batteries etc.) ad 0,6 - 0.7 mm enamel wire for the loading coil. The radiator should be made ca. 5 m long so that the coil sits ca 1m above ground.

The coil should be ca 1 - 2 turns for 20m, 6 - 7 more for 30m, and 8 more for 40m, but you need to tune this to resonance..

Use 2mm plugs to shorten the parts of the coil not needed for the band in use.

More details are here: http://reflector.sota.org.uk/t/sota-vertical-antenna-for-40-30-20m/15673.

You can fit in a small balun behind the BNC plug; use 11 turns of twisted enamel wire on a FT50-43 toroid then.

Enjoy!

73 de Martin, DK3IT

Edit 2018-03-15: As a compact winder for winding up the tuned radials, I recommend the design from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1173824/ but scaled to 66% in the X and Y axis and 100% for the Z axis (3 mm high).

title: Throw-away slick wheel for RC car (Traxxas E-Revo 1:16 but adaptable)

description.text:
Traxxas E-Revo 1:16 slicks

EDIT: I made a blog post about this. you can find it here: http://blog.octomy.org/2017/07/creality-cr10-cura-settings.html

Original design: Lennart Rolland.
For project: OctoMY™ (http://octomy.org).
Description: This is the first of a series of experimental designs for 3D printed wheels for Traxxas E-Revo 1:16 RC car. It is designed to be easily adaptible to other RC cars.
Please note: This is a prototype design that has already been superseeded by better ideas.

Pros

  • It fit the wheel mount of the car on first try!
  • The low mass made it really accellerate fast.
  • The slick design was fun to drive.
  • The spokes worked really well.

Cons

  • The outer wall thickness ("tire surface") was too thin and running over gravel poked holes in it on the first run.
  • The hex part of the mounting hole was to shallow. Will add more depth in the next iteration
  • The thickness of the wall in the hex part of the mounting hole felt too thin, and will be increased by 2mm in the next iteration

Overal: Albeit the obvious room for improvement I am still quite happy with the result!

Standard disclaimer: This work is provided as a convenience and for informational purposes only. The original author assumes no responsibility for any adverse effects that may arrise from this work.

Copyright / license: I hereby place this work into the public domain, though if you want to show appreciation and you have robot parts to spare, please consider donating them to the OctoMY™ project http://www.octomy.org/contribute/donation ).

title: Frame Brace with y-axis motor mount and screw holes (Anet A8)

description.text:
Intended to be used to strengthen the acrylic frame on which the Y-axis motor is mounted, so it doesn't bend.

This is a remix with screw holes added. I've also tried to simplify the model, so it would be easier to print.
Do note that it took 13 hours for me to print.
Black print is "Version 2 MotorAntiVib"
White print is "Version 1"

Version 1 (The white print)
My original modification, which is the one printed in white. I recommend you go with version 2 instead, as it's nicer with the extra wiring holes. :)

Version 2
v2 have extra wiring holes, and also moved one of the screw holes closer to the rest of the model. The side walls have also been increased a bit, to make space for the extra wiring holes.

Version 2 MotorAntiVib (The black print)
Is a modification of v2, with space for 6mm deep vibration dampener (Also known as stepper dampener).
I use these: http://www.ebay.com/itm/Shock-Absorber-Stepper-Vibration-Damper-For-Nema17-3D-Printer-DIY-Accessories-H5/282265613600
The floor and side-wall at the motor have also been lowered by 3mm, to make space for various dampening materials, that you can use to rest the motor on if you wish.
Note that the dampener is represented in the skethup picture as the part in orange.

print_settings.Notes:: For screws, I used some #6 pan phil x 3/8" long (Flat heads would also work) and nylock nuts on the inside.  It was slightly tricky getting the back two nuts in place.. I dropped one a corner, used a finger to flip it in the right position then held it in place with that finger while I started the screw threading into it from the backside.  Once started, I tightened it until it was maybe a turn away from fully compressed.. then started the next corner.  Once all 4 screws were in place, I completed tightening it. Print with the clips facing up and the flat side down, and use supports underneath.  They should clean out easily from the bottom or side with a pocket knife.

author: Brentox

description.text:
Just a simple vape stand to hold 2 istick picos, 2 spare batteries, 3 30mL bottles of juice, and spare coils.

There were a few vape stands already on Thingiverse, but I couldn't find any that held 2 picos with room for all of the extras, so I whipped this up in 123d Design.

If you're looking for something to accommodate bigger bottles, check out my V2 design: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2768473

Or, to hold your picos in the car: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2768508

I admit I am a bit neurotic when it comes to my iPhone case. After designing nearly ten separate cases, I was still on the hunt for my perfect design. I hate that we take a thin, light phone, and wrap it in a bulky case. I have various charging docks that require most cases to be removed. Lastly, I wanted a printed case that did not loosen over time, one that can hold onto the phone with more grip than the normal edge grip variety. The X corner case provides full coverage to the phone, including fully wrapped corners, while retaining the thin, light feeling of the phone. In fact, the normal grip of the phone barely feels the presence of the case at all. The case prints in two pieces, and locks into place using the pressure of the phone itself. It is designed to allow compatibility to docks such a iHome. Simply the sleekest, lightest, less obtrusive functional case available. There are two versions located here: A standard version with holes cut out to provide a more industrial look, and a Makerbot special edition. Enjoy - and feedback is always welcome! If you really like the design, consider ordering one from Shapeways in smooth nylon print here: http://www.shapeways.com/shops/raedenware

This case was a challenge both from a design, as well as a printing perspective.  Because the corners are fully wrapped, printing a single piece would create difficult overhangs.  After experimenting with various ways to connect seperate pieces, I designed a rabbet interlock that not only aligns the segments, but creates a lock that prevents the segments from turning (see video).  Place the segment with the camera cutout onto the phone first.  On the inside of the second segment, a small arrow denotes the top of the phone.  Place this segment on, turning into the corners to align the groove.  Press the two pieces into one another until they seat firmly together.  To remove, simply lift the second segment in the middle and slide off.  
I print in PLA using .1 layer thickness, and I tend to use a raft (not supports).  The part should print fine without a raft on a well leveled bed.

description.text:
This adapter will fit an Anker 48W 4-Port USB Car Charger in a 1990 Nissan 240SX in the center console next to the cigarette lighter. You can splice into the cigarette wires to power the Anker charger.

I recommend printing out of ABS due to the heat on a sunny day.

There is a split in the design that will print joined, this means you must install the charger with the wires through the adapter. If you slice the split with a knife (please be careful) then you can snap the adapter around the charger after wiring up and the split shouldn't be very noticeable.

Link to the charger I used:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00WHXRGL4/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

title: Printrbot Smalls (LE, Limited Edition) Spool Holder

description.text:
Printrbot Smalls LE Spool Holder

May work on Printrbot Smalls Standard Edition as well

An angled spool holder to hold spools up to ~95mm wide.

Gravity keeps spools in place (held against the angled base of the holder) while printing.

Install next to the handle where the spool holder points upward.

Your spool of filament should rest against the holder base and angle away from and over the printer Y-carriage metal arm.

Holds Minimum Spool Diameter of ~30mm.

Attaches using two screws that are around 5mm longer than the original M3 screws.

You may also be able to remove the handle and use the original screws and attach this where the handle goes.

This holds all of the 1kg/2.2lb spools I have tested.

author: michaelkuty

description.text:
This the latest revision of my 5mm to 8mm shaft coupler. This design has a reduced overall size for limited space.
It also intended to protect your Z axis in the event of a crash. The coupler should fail before your Z axis is driven through your build platform or end stops when it encounters significant resistance. I have tested this coupler on a printrbot Plus V1 and a Prusa i3 with good results. The revision 8 couplers are designed with two locking screws per shaft and are intended for higher torque requirements. These are not the damage preventing type. I will upload the revision 9 version soon that will incorporate a damage reducing failure feature.

Also in the projects files tab, you can find my GCode for Prusa MK2 (PET)

Finishing

Grip

I recomend to sand the whole part, than you are touching and if you are able, get some very big linear ballons and put a piece of it on the handl. It isn't necessary, but it gives much nicer grip.

Mini Shoe

Only one modification is needed to be done to the bottom part. About 2mm from bottom there are two grooves visualy separating the upper part from the downer. Every camera has diferent gripping notch thickness so you would need to eventualy file it to the right size.

Optional

Maybe you would need to break the two slim pins at bottom to decrese hazard of breaking them in the camera it self.

description.text:
I wanted to have a screen to put stuff like the camera on the printer, and I have this old syrupy slow WindPad tablet. I put a fresh Xubuntu on it and started to watch the camera, but the viewing angles were crap and leaning it against a speaker gave me mono sound. Not a good combo.

The monitor is a Dell P2314H and the size of the pole is about 70x40 mm.

Started thinking about attaching it atop of one of my monitors and found that the upright of the monitor stand seemed fairly sturdy so I figured i could do something with it.

The main parts are:

  • Monitor mount adapter to 20mm pipe.
  • 20mm plastic electric pipe
  • Bottom tablet stand, the groove is a bit wide, I use a bit of blue-tack to stop the tablet from sliding around. The bottom stand rests on the top of the monitor.
  • Adjustable top tablet holder, to let you set the angle of the tablet with M4 nut, washer and 20mm screw.

It should be easy to attach anything to the pipe that's fairly light.

Designed in OnShape: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/84308ad2a91e72a637497740/w/b01964a3e37ecdb7ffc3df1f/e/6c6df7c7d51e59c9f6207e5d

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Nothing special to it, should print great without any supports.

Prep the pipe

You could use the pipe as it is but you might want to sand it to get rid of text on it, make it easier to fit or prep it for painting, it's up to you. But if you want to sand the pipe do it before the other parts.

Mount the pipe

Put the pipe in the part that sits on the monitor stand. The fit should be tight but i could get it to the bottom of the hole by pushing against the floor. I kept about 30 cm above the monitors highest position to have plenty of space for future upgrades.

Fit the tablet holder to the pipe

Test fit and and sand both tablet mount holes until you can slide it on the pipe with a bit of force without it binding and making a lot of noise. You can look for shiny spots on the inside of the mount to find the high spots, sand them down and test again. Don't make it too loose or it might move by it self.

Put the upper mount together

Put the M4 nut (7mm between it's flat sides) in the wing nut's trap. Put the washer on the screw and stick it through the hole in the front part. Put the rear part that attaches to the pipe upside down over the screw and screw on the wing nut.

Put it all together

Put the lower mount on the pipe, then the upper mount. Put the whole thing on your monitor and set your monitor height as you want it. Set the bottom mount so it just touch the top of your monitor. Set the height of the top mount so your tablet won't fall out. Slide in the tablet and fine tune everything.

Remix de DYOR

I didn't like clipping my dogs nails because the pressure hurt him so I bought a grinder which turned out to be very weak. I had a Dremel 4000 which with the barrel attachment was basically the same thing as the grinder, only it had much more torque. Screw the adapter onto the Dremel, turn it to the lowest setting, insert your dogs nail into the elongated oval hole, and watch the nails grind down. Do not use a high setting as it will grind the nail too quickly and cause heat to build up.

I am not liable for harm done to your pet. It is very important to know where the quick is on your dogs nails and not to cut into it. Doing so will cause profuse bleeding. I suggest reading a how-to on properly grinding nails.

comments.author: DanCrank

description.text:
This is a pen gripper designed for a Rostock 3D printer. I designed it to allow me to use my printer as a plotter.
  • Print the pen gripper.
  • Put a screw through each of the 6 holes on the posts.
  • Thread a nut onto each screw.
  • With a screwdriver, turn each screw until the nut gets pulled into its cavity. It will be a tight fit.
  • Attach the gripper to your print head using the 3 holes on the corners.
  • Place a pen vertically in the place where all 6 gripper screws come together. Make sure the pen is positioned correctly so it will reach the paper when the print head is at Z=0.
    • You may now generate G-code and send it to your printer to be plotted! I'll be working on code to convert an SVG file into G-code.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These OBJ models are designed for use in Sculptris and are designed to work with my Sculptris Dummies.. If you import them into Sculptris, their parts should remain separate and you can immediately begin sculpting and posing them any way you like. All of these parts are also available in Andrew Stockton's awesome Desktop Hero project as well (which is quite a bit easier than adjusting all the parts by hand).

If you make anything with these (including through Desktop Hero), let me know and post a link here in the comments section (and certainly post a remix when you have something printable). I'd love to see what you come up with!

You can find an expanding collection of compatible parts here.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

comments.text: Just wanted to say thanks for putting together all these bits packages.  So great for helping people assemble their own models and learn a bit about the tools available for 3D modeling in the process.
comments.author: Annatar2

comments.text: You're very welcome! Also, once Desktop Hero is open to the public, there'll be a much faster way (though I know modifying the parts in Sculptris is great for people who want to learn how to sculpt/use that program).

description.text:
I give up. I GIVE UP! I have gone out at different times of day and re-shot this statue 5 times trying to get a good capture for 123D Catch. No matter what I do this is the best I've managed to do. It looks okay from a distance, but up close the detail sucks. Club hands, no face, and random spiky things. Any attempt to manually stitch in pictures just seems to make things WORSE.
So I'm going to upload the original pictures and hope that someone can make it work where I didn't or tell me what I need to do. All these pictures were taken in a single setting at the same time.
All I wanted was a plastic Jesus riding on the dashboard of my car.
(This isn't the original Salt Lake Christus.. It's a reproduction that is near my work in Provo. So I'm trying to make a print of a scan of a reproduction.)

comments.text: The pictures need to be of the same scale, ie have the full view of the statue. The close up shots while showing more detail will not be able to be incorporated because they don't have a good frame of reference. I'm going to try uploading just the full images and see how it does.

title: Dungeon Dolls: Ork
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ever like the variable designs of FlatMinis, but the customization of Dungeon Dolls? Ever wanted more options? Look no further! Inspired by the aesthetic of GrumpyRobot's FlatMinis, and DutchMogul's Dungeon Doll system, come Trixster_98's take on the classic Dungeon Doll.

These handy Orks include a stone machete, a large hammer with or without spikes, pants with pouches, shirt with chest straps attached via a ring, 4 heads with either scaring, a mohawk, a ponytail, or plain, either a plain base or one with a standard coming out the back equipable with either a flag or skull of you choice, and a bottom. Try mixing with other characters for more types of weapons, skulls for the standard, pants, and armour. I printed mine at 150% which stands at 42 mm to the head, and 75 mm tall standard. Fully customizable and modular, look for more designs to come in the following weeks.

These designs are fully compatible with DutchMogul's original Dungeon Dolls, but not with FlatMinis
Made in Tinkercad, printed on my Monoprice MP Select Mini

Printing
The pieces should be printed at 150-200% depending on what you feel your printers accuracy to be. My printer can make all the details clearly visible at 100% but needs the print to be at 150% in order to fit together well.
The picture shows the 3 sizes of 200%, 150%, and 100%

Preparation
In order for the pieces to properly fit together, you will need to lightly sand them with a set of needle files. The heads just need very minute sanding in the eye holes. My first layer is always slightly off which always needs work in that one spot. The studs that attach to the shirt and pants need light sanding, but the holes should be fine, depending on your printers accuracy. The shirt stud typically needs a very small amount of sanding compared to the pant studs. The bottom that fits onto the base will most likely need sanding on both the hole and stud depending on accuracy.

Always test fit pieces together as you sand. I'm not responsible for ruined pieces due to too much sanding.

it is a custom made car prototype

This is my remix of Colorado_CJ's Container Box.
Technically it is not a simple remix because it is designed from scratch, based on Colorado_CJ's dimensions.
My quad is not an ARFun 90 but an Awesome 90 (which is the same quad) and my design can hold 3x 450mah 3S nanotech lipos, couple of 2" props and some other smaller stuff.
I also made the top box cover 2mm taller so now the usable height for the quad is 32mm.
I hope you like it!
Happy printing! :)

tip:
if you have trouble with non sticky letters on your heatbed of the top piece, try print awesome_90_box_top_letters file instead. I removed all the hard-to-stick letter parts!

Inspirated from Wersy's Boats, I decide to build a more powerfull Boat.
After browsing the whole net, i found nothing to be good enough to be printed.
So i sit down at my PC and draw a new one.The idea was to build the "Mystic Miss Geico".
Now it's ready to be posted.
It's a 29" Catamaran and i think it's very fast as an 3D printed Boat.
I printed it with PLA (easy to print) with the standard Settings:
Outer Shells 3
Bottom Layers 3
Top Layers 3
Infill i used is 20% except 3.stl and v.stl they are 10%

All Files are arranged to print without Support Material,
The best glue for PLA is Dichlormethan, you can find it on net,
and put some small pieces of PLA into it (ca.20-30%PLA) for a few hours,
so you get a very good glue for PLA

I posted the whole Hull and Cockpit, if someone want to Cut or Scale it by himself

Good Succeed

the Videos you can see here:
https://youtu.be/OTwGGEGWpyc
https://youtu.be/4WLjYlLCVXA

PS: we glued the inner "Hole" with one thin fiber glass layer, it seems to be unstable.
The fantastic Airbrush did a friend of mine,it's awesome

Post 9.08.2017
i posted some new stl files to my project, i splited the whole hull in the left and right side,
for people with smaller printers
i hope this is helpfull , now you can rotate and cut the height by yourseft specialy for your printer

description.text:
This is a Y-Axis Belt tensioner for the prusa I3 rework. It has 4 M3x40mm in my case but you can use larger (more longer makes a minor travel distance of the axis).

For a perfect tension i also used a holder that can resist the tension(https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:745934).

Step for a good tension:
1.- Put the belt in the holder and around the motor and the bearing (608zz already put in the M8 bolt to the part of the thing.
2.- Put the M3 bolts to the nut of the other part and tensioner all you can the holder of the bed.
3.- Tensioner the 4 M3 turning them by small parts untill you see the belt as you want.

Good luck and if you have an answer i wait you in the comment section.

title: Dungeon Dolls: Goblin
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ever like the variable designs of FlatMinis, but the customization of Dungeon Dolls? Ever wanted more options? Look no further! Inspired by the aesthetic of GrumpyRobot's FlatMinis, and DutchMogul's Dungeon Doll system, come Trixster_98's take on the classic Dungeon Doll.

These handy Goblins include a small axe, a large axe, a small knife, a large double sided knife with two different handle placements, a fancy round shield, pants with pouches or plain pants, shirt with massive showy pauldrons or a plain shirt (shown also is the Guard Moon top from the insignia package), 2 heads with either a large helmet or plain goblin head, a plain base, and a bottom. Try mixing with other characters for more types of weapons, pants, and armour. I printed mine at 150% which stands at 42 mm to the head.
Fully customizable and modular, look for more designs to come in the following weeks.

These designs are fully compatible with DutchMogul's original Dungeon Dolls, but not with FlatMinis
Made in Tinkercad, printed on my Monoprice MP Select Mini

Printing
The pieces should be printed at 150-200% depending on what you feel your printers accuracy to be. My printer can make all the details clearly visible at 100% but needs the print to be at 150% in order to fit together well.
The picture shows the 3 sizes of 200%, 150%, and 100%

Preparation
In order for the pieces to properly fit together, you will need to lightly sand them with a set of needle files. The heads just need very minute sanding in the eye holes. My first layer is always slightly off which always needs work in that one spot. The studs that attach to the shirt and pants need light sanding, but the holes should be fine, depending on your printers accuracy. The shirt stud typically needs a very small amount of sanding compared to the pant studs. The bottom that fits onto the base will most likely need sanding on both the hole and stud depending on accuracy.

Always test fit pieces together as you sand. I'm not responsible for ruined pieces due to too much sanding.

Easy to print replacement casing for the Ultimaker 2 sliding block plastic mold.

  • Mounted with screws instead of interlocks - easy to print
  • Tight belt grip - zero backlash due to the tension spring wobbling
  • Tight 6mm rod grip with set screw - rod will never fall out of this one!
  • No tension included! - you can put the tension spring on the other half of the belt

To replace all four slider blocks you need:

  • 4 x 11mm/12mm x 30mm x 8mm sintered bushings from the original slider blocks
  • 8 x M3 12mm machine screws
  • 8 x M3 hex nuts
  • Either 4 x M3 10mm screws or 4 x M3 set screws

There are two sets of STL files. One for 11mm bushings, and one for 12 mm bushings (outer diameter).

The STL files have reasonable deviations for the bushing and 6mm rod, but you may need to drill the 6mm rod hole to get the rod to fit. The screw holes have 0.2mm overhang that need to be drilled with a 3mm drill bit.

The blocks fit either way around. I recommend putting the screws on the inside for maximum build volume. You can also mirror the blocks.

title: mSATA to SATA adapter enclosure for PC Engines APU/APU2

description.text:
This is another way to use the SATA port which is present on all PC Engines APU/APU2 boards.

It's actually an enclosure for an mSATA to SATA adapter, that I combined with my miniPCI dummy/placeholder (I used a small velcro strip to attach them to each other for stability). The linked adapter just slides into the enclosure.

Note that it seems to be increasingly difficult to find SSD with mSATA connectors, as the format is apparently being phased out and replaced by M.2. I found this adapter which lets you use a 42mm (or 30mm, should you find one) M.2 SSD in an mSATA slot. I haven't tested it myself yet, but I will update the text here once I've done so.

For my next build I might also use this M.2 to SATA adapter directly, and adapt the enclosure accordingly (should be fairly easy as the OpenSCAD file is entirely parametric).

remixed_from.author: dkj4linux
remixed_from.title: MPCNC 2826/2822 Brushless RC Motor Foam Cutter

title: Improved Needle Cutter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Based on djk4linux's work as discussed in the FlightTest Forums here: http://forum.flitetest.com/showthread.php?24251-Cutting-foam-sheets-with-a-needle

My work on this version starts at this post: http://forum.flitetest.com/showthread.php?24251-Cutting-foam-sheets-with-a-needle!&p=356850&viewfull=1#post356850

I'm using the cutter_body.stl version which is designed to work with hicwic's quick change mount. I've also included a hacked up cutter_body-525.stl which should mount to the new stock 525 style tool mount...however since I haven't upgraded my MPCNC yet I have not tested that particular mount. When I do upgrade my machine (or when I get bored) I'll draw up a nicer optimized mount for the 525...unless someone beats me to it :D

Introduction to this version:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nYEQ5p_Yi5k

Cutting a full sheet with this cutter:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eCKBj7OnG7o

Onshape project:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/0b010a7a70bd0183d800fa80/w/2427c16d54be94a0c0fb03df/e/6104b1396ce31afa164ac429

9/20/17 - Added "cutter_body - New-mount-52.stl" version with the distance between the motor mounting face and the needle guide stretched to 52mm to allow more motor options with dkj4linux's original "prop saver" mount style flywheel.

Printer:

Folgertech 2020 i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The cutter body prints without supports at 15-20% infill and at least 3 perimeters for strength. It's pretty forgiving how you print it.

The flywheel however needs support and at least 25% infill and 5 perimeters for best performance. I print it with the four small mounting holes facing down (180 degrees from the default orientation) and slic3r set to give 0.5mm XY spacing on support to make the little support pieces easier to remove after printing.

Required parts

Small piece of hardwood for insulator
Length of 0.62mm/0.025" music wire (at least 6" long)
5 - 693ZZ - 8mm OD x 3mm ID x 4mm thick bearings.
5 - 2.5mm washers with ID drilled out to 3mm. (3mm washers with an OD that doesn't interfere with the outer race of the bearings would work as well.)
9 - M3 x 10mm machine screws
Assorted M3 screws/washers for counterweight
2 - M3 x 16mm machine screws (for mounting insulator)
2 - M3 nuts (nyloc prefered but regular probably ok.)
4 - M2 x 6mm screws (for attaching the flywheel to the motor)
2212 sized 850kv motor and ESC to control it - needs 2mm holes in face for mounting the flywheel.

Optional - strip of 3 12v LED's.

Flywheel assembly

The holes in the flywheel are sized so M3 screws can self-tap. You can use a tap to start the threads but I suggest NOT tapping the full depth with a tap so the screws fit tighter.

The holes around the outside of the flywheel are so you can balance it before fitting the bearing/needle if necessary.

I use the inner most of the 3 possible locations to mount my bearing - on my flywheel this is 7mm from the center so gives 14mm of stroke on the needle (djk4linux's original design was 6mm from the center for 12mm of stroke - but I needed to move mine out so the flywheel could fit closer to the motor.)

Behind the bearing you'll want a washer that fits over an M3 screw but which does not rub against the outer race. The M3 washers I was able to find locally were not suitable for this as their OD was too large. So I opted to drill out an M2.5 washer so it fit over a M3 screw.

djk4linux suggests grinding a groove into the outer race of the bearing to help retain the needle - I tried this but damaged my bearing in the process. I'm currently using an ungrooved bearing and it's working fine for me I just made sure the coils on my needle were undersized so it fits VERY snugly on the bearing. A 623vv grooved bearing may be another good option but it's 10mm OD instead of 8 so a little bigger. Moebeast is using a 10mm bearing on his and has also created a printable needle retainer that he's testing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2429886

Once the bearing/washer/needle are mounted the flywheel should be placed on a shaft and balanced. I used a shorter 8mm M3 screw with 2 M3 washers in the outside hole which seemed to balance out perfectly against my needle.

The flywheel is then mounted to the motor with 4 2M screws these can be hard to find...I used mounting screws that came with a 1806 brushless motor that I had worn out. Another option may be to disassemble an older notebook as M2 screws are sometimes used for assembly on notebook computers.

Needle Details

The needle is made from a length of 0.25"/0.62mm music wire (sometimes called piano wire). It's best to start with a piece that's longer than you'll need since it makes forming the attaching coil easier.

When bending the wire it's best to use round nosed jewelers pliers to avoid putting any stress risers into the wire. I formed mine by selecting a drill around 4mm (roughly half the size of the bearing) and just grabbing it about 6" from either end and twisting it around the drill shaft twice then trimming it off. I then used the round nosed pliers to slightly tighten the coils and to put a small bend where the needle comes off the bearing so the wire leaves the bearing centered instead of off to one side. This turned out to make a BIG difference in how smoothly the cutter runs - but if not done carefully can create a stress in the wire making this the most likely place the needle will break.

The needle is then installed into the cutter and trimmed to length before sharpening. I like to sneak up on the length since I usually loose a bit of length while sharpening. For cutting foamboard you only need about 6.5-8mm of needle protruding from the guide. The less that protrudes the more accurate your cutter will be. The needle should retract fully into the guide on the upstroke.

I sharpen the needle by removing it from the cutter and rotating it in my fingers while holding it against a cutoff disc in a dremel at a sharp angle. It doesn't take much and even a fairly dull needle cuts well.

Needle guide

The two most popular needle guides are either a MIG welder tip or an sports ball inflation needle. In my experience the sports ball inflation needle runs cooler - but wears out quicker and is more likely to deflect in use and cost accuracy.

Because the guide can get warm from the friction of the needle running inside of it it's best to use a heat resistant insulator to mount the guide to the 3D printed cutter body. I originally used soft pine but had my guide come loose mid-cut and ruin a sheet of foam so have since switched to hard oak. I cut the insulator from a piece of 1/4" x 1" wood which I hold up to the cutter then trace around the cutter body so I can cut it to final shape on a bandsaw (or just sand it down to match.) The guide hole should be drilled to a size that allows your guide to self-tap (or you can tap it if you know what size tap matches your guide.) The guide should be centered under the needle. The two retaining screws get their holes drilled using the cutter body as a guide to position them.

Guide Bearings.

These are optional but highly recommended. They help straighten the motion of the needle before it enters the guide greatly reducing the friction in the guide itself. They are mounted with M3 x 10mm screws self-tapped into the cutter body with M3 washers behind them. Drilled out M2.5 washers would probably be better but I haven't had any issues with M3 washers on these.

Depending on the dimensions of your motor and how your needle mounts to the flywheel bearing you may need to adjust the washers behind these or the flywheel bearing to make sure the needle runs as close to centered as possible through the bearings. The printed bearing standoffs should allow bearings to be mounted with no washers if the need arises.

LEDs / Wiring

The LED's were simply stuck to the bottom and then wired to the power input connections on the ESC for the brushless motor.

I'm using a 25a ESC but this is overkill, the motor draws very little current so even a 6a ESC is more than enough for this application.

Motor Considerations

My original cutter used a higher kv motor which I had to run off 7.4v to keep it at the ideal RPM range. For this cutter I switched to a slower 850kv motor so I can run it directly off 12v (the same as the LED's require and what the rest of my MPCNC runs on) This cutter body is really designed around the motor. The motor came from a bin of parts I have but is most likely this one: http://store.jdrones.com/AC2830_358_Motors_p/ac2830358.htm However similar motors are available from a number of other sources. While jdrones refers to it as a 2830 motor (because they measure the bell) most other manufacturers/retailers classify this as a 2212 motor (based on the size of the stator) There is a model of the motor included in the Onshape document so you can confirm dimensions.

comments.text: If the ESC has a built in BEC then it will output 5v.  A lot of newer ESC's for the multirotor market now eliminate the BEC to save money/heat/weight since you only need one per vehicle and multirotors usually run a separate power distribution board that incorporates a BEC instead.  So, yes receivers run on 5v and if your ESC outputs voltage back to the receiver it will be 5v.

comments.author: jhitesma

comments.text: No wiring diagram...but FT have done a video or two on how to use them.  I don't have links handy.  Basically you wire your 3s battery to your ESC, then just plug the ESC into the servo tester.  If the ESC has a built in BEC then it will power the batter tester.  If it doesn't have a BEC you'll have to plug just part of the balance connector in to feed one cell's worth of voltage to the servo tester.  If you feel full 3s or even 2s power to the servo tester you'll burn it out.

comments.text: It actually stays much cooler than I expected.  The last time I tried using a mig tip I was using a .035" mig tip with thicker wire. comments.author: pete7919

comments.text: One more question:  Is this the tip I need?
comments.author: jhitesma

comments.text: I'm using a 0.030" tip for the 0.025" wire.  You want the tip to be a little bigger so there's not too much friction.  Some people even use the 0.035" tip which will run a little cooler but gives a tiny bit less accuracy.

What you can see here is a plain wall mount for an very old iPod Touch. The design itself is nothing special, contains some errors actually and was one of the first designs I created.
Even though it's simple and not done that well, it became one of my most used 3d printed items.

Why did I upload it?

Well, even though it's not one of the best designs, it still looks quite smooth and definitely good enough for daily use.
The actual reason why I uploaded this file is because of the idea behind it.
My problem with smart homes today is that you mostly have to use your phone: You need to pick it up, start the app, go through several menus and all of that only to change the brightness of a lightbulb or something.
Having a cleaned up interface just above the normal light switches made my "smart home life" a lot easier. As soon as I walk into the room, I can turn on my TV or PC. I can turn off the lights in the corridor, if I forgot to turn them off and also turn off the TV without walking back to the remote.
Even though these examples sound like first world problems, believe me, it is a great benefit for smart homes. And considering the fact, that many of us have some old smartphones laying around, it's quite cheap as well.

So after all I uploaded this to give you an idea on how to make "smart homes" really accesible. A smart phone as a remote is annyoing and takes a lot of time and assistants like Alexa aren't good enough (yet, at least not for my purposes).

How does it work?

openHAB (https://www.openhab.org/) is a great open-source software that lets you do everything you want with your smart home devices. It is properly the software that supports most of the smart home devices out there and it runs on a RPi!.
But to be honest, it's not the easiest software to use, especially if you want to do weird things, BUT you can do really EVERYTHING.
To have a nice and clean interface, I put together some HTML, CSS and JS, hardcoded the openHAB items to the buttons you can see in the describing picture and hosted all that stuff on my NAS.
This is definitely not the best solution though and the code almost smells bad, but it works consistently. If you plan on recreating this, you should have a look at openHABs different user interfaces.

How to print and use

I printed it standing, just like in the model. I noticed that the hole at the bottom isn't open in slicing software, but it should be. Not sure if it's just a display error or if it's also printing like that. If your slicing software closes the hole for the charger, maybe just move the model lower, under the "bed" in the slicer software until the hole is open again.
As I said, one of my first designs.
I recommend to use some felt over the screws. Not because of scratching (the heads of the screws should remain in the sinks) but to make the iPod sit tight in the mount.

I scored 20 of these rocker switches on ebay for only US$pi, so now I'm looking for places to use them. Here's a design that conveniently mounts a rocker switch onto a 40mm fan without restricting airflow. You just snap the switch into place and wire it up. There's a spacer in the middle of the switch that allows you to mount it along with my 40mm Adjustable Fan Mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:239985) . I should point out that although it's shown in the photo mounted to an X carriage, that's probably not the best place for it if you want to switch it on and off while printing. I have a switch panel version -- similar to my fully printable switch panel (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30348) -- that I'll post soon. You will probably need to clip the switch leads a bit -- I didn't want to make the housing unnecessarily tall. Switches: Last I checked, you can still get 20 switches for US$3.14, shipping included on ebay. Search "20 Pcs Boat Rocker Switch"

remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Specific Y-Axis Carriage Plate Upgrade

description.text:
If you want to use a regular 220mmx220mm Dibond/Aluminum plate as carriage for your Anet A8/A6, you need spaces so it does not hit the motor. I have cut out the shape of the original carriage from Ecto1A to be a tiny spacer.

Print four of them and use matching screws (M4x16?) to attach to your aluminum plate to the axis thingies.

If you need a guide for drilling the holes, just use your old H-frame for it.

OpenSCAD file and resources attached.

Insert for "Ball Jar" to hold a cut-out "Scotch Bright" sponge.

Use 300 mL glue solution to ensure air gap: sponge vs liquid.

Shake closed jar after application, to refresh glue on the sponge.

Customize with OnShape

author: paintedboots

title: Tripod and Orb Stand for a Glow Cloud
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a stand and adapter piece that was designed as a stand for a glow cloud. The full write up is here.

There are two parts, both designed in OpenSCAD. The stand itself is a tripod/orb, with a hole in the top of the orb to fit the adapter piece. The adapter is attached to the glow cloud itself.

The tripod/orb is a tricky part to print. I'm using an E3D V6 Volcano with the 0.8mm nozzle on a Printrbot Simple Metal with upgraded Z and X axes, printing a 0.6mm layer height at 30mm/sec. It'll be around 6-7 hours at that setting. It is designed to not require support material. It is around 10 inches high and 6 inches wide. I used clear PLA for mine.

I recommend trimming the part down to just the orb, and try printing the orb first. Otherwise, you may get the legs right, but then find out after wasting a ton of material that the orb is not working out at all. It took me 5 tries to get the whole thing to work.

author: readmodifywrite

description.text: Stands for circuit

Adaptador para el proyecto https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2425987 que permite montar la ground station de pitlab.

Montaje: https://youtu.be/D5-VsytRrnc

This is a case for a bench power supply that uses a standard ATX computer power supply and a DPS 5005. I really wanted to make a cheap bench power supply for use with my electronics project. This design allows you to use the 12v, 5v, 3.3v from the ATX PSU and the DPS 5005 for a variable output from 0-11.1V. The DPS 5005 gives you constant voltage and current modes, as well as various protection features.

I hot glue the led, usb jack and nuts in place. Then used quick disconnects for the on/off switch and ring terminals for the banana jacks. The led and usb connections were soldered.

Parts List:

  • DPS 5005
  • Banana Plug Jack
  • On/Off Switch
  • Female USB Socket

I got these at Home Depot, but here are some examples for reference.

  • Ring Terminal for back of Banana Plug Jack
  • Female Quick Disconnect
  • four #4-40 x 3/8 in screws and nuts
  • Rubber Standoff, I had some old ones laying around. I can't find them online though.
  • your choice of LED and appropriate Resistor for 5v.
  • Power Resistor. Maybe. It seems newer power supplies are stable without a load on it, but if you use an older one you might need this. If most of your power is on the 5v rail, you need about 10Ω 2.5w. If most of your power is on the 12v rail, you need about 24Ω 6w.

Tools:

  • Hot Glue Gun
  • Soldering Iron
  • Wire Cutters/strippers
  • Crimpers
  • Screw Drivers

Good References:

  • Make: Turn a Computer Power Supply into Bench Power
  • Search Youtube: "GreatScott! DIY Lab Bench Power Supply"
  • Instructables - GreatScott! DIY Lab Bench Power Supply

Notes:

use pla. pla has better layer bonding than some others like abs. solid fill for good feel. supports are pre-added in files. may need to adjust extrusion width/multiplier.

Tweeks...

"squish-out" can make bottom holes too small. use a 2.75 mm to 2.8 mm wide flat head screwdriver or a 2.5 mm hex wrench to bore these holes bigger.

Clean up

use a good sharp hobby knife to remove supports, burrs, and squish-outed edges.

how I did it (in a nutshell)

downloaded the "assembled" version of original for reference. measured a die. it was about 16.2 mm. took off 0.2 mm for extrusion width; left with 16mm. made a blank piece (16x(16/3)x(16/3)) and closed file. copied 9 more of file. renamed. opened the 9 files (the other is for backup). for each file added holes and studs with a 3 degree taper. holes are 3 mm (min d) x 1 mm (deep). pegs are 2.8 mm (min d) x 1 mm (tall). arrangement of the pegs and holes are the same as reference except an added hole for laughs :-D

to assemble:
front is the 6, bottom is the 4.
bottom (front to back):
files 1,2, and 3
middle (left to right):
files 4,5, and 6
top (front to back):
files 7,8, and 9
